did.abstract: Affirmations Lesbian/Gay Community Center was established in 1989 to serve as a resource to lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender individuals in the greater Detroit area. The records consist of meeting minutes, correspondence, and written records pertaining to Affirmationsâ€™ fundraising, programming, membership and advocacy activities. Select events are also documented by photographs.

bioghist.p: Affirmations Lesbian/Gay Community Center was founded in 1989 based on the philosophy that "gay is good, you are not alone." Originally established as offshoot of the Michigan Organization for Human Rights (MOHR), Affirmations provided the greater Detroit area with Switchboard (renamed Helpline in October 1994), a volunteer-staffed telephone support line that has continued as one of the organization's hallmark programs. Since its inception, the non-profit has established community groups; open discussion groups; recreation and social activities; seminars, workshops and training programs; and a significant youth services program.

Jan Stevenson, the first President of the Board of Directors, steered Affirmations in its early stages before assuming the role of Executive Director in 1991. During her tenure, the organization flourished and expanded to approximately 1,700 members at its peak in 1995. Julie Enszer, formerly the Program Director, succeeded Stevenson as Executive Director in late 1995.

Between 1995 and 1997, the youth services program grew to approximately half of the organization's work. In the process, Affirmations developed from its initial role as a support-group to that of a community-builder. To reflect this shift, the organization adopted a new mission statement in 1997: "Affirmations Lesbian/Gay Community Center works to achieve respect and equality for gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people through social service programs, advocacy, and education. Affirmations provides services to empower individuals and families, to build a cohesive community and to fulfil our responsibilities in society."

The late-1990s ushered in an era of financial difficulty as Affirmations operated at a loss from 1997 to 1999. This instability was worsened by high staff turnover, including the resignation of the entire staff by September 1999. With the departure of Executive Director Cindy Woodbury, the operation of Affirmations was left to the Board and volunteers until Leslie Ann Thompson assumed the role in October 1999.

Despite the turmoil of 1999, 2000 proved to be the organization's strongest year since 1995. Affirmations continued to develop new programs to service the community, and it responded to changing social attitudes toward the gay community by placing greater emphasis on its youth services and diversity programs.

scopecontent.p: This collection reflects the operational and planning activities for Affirmations Lesbian/Gay Community Center. It is divided into nine series: Background, Governance, Administration, Grants and Fundraising, Programming, Membership and Volunteers, Advocacy, Publicity, and Photographs. The majority of the collection has been arranged alphabetically by topic and chronologically within files.

The Background series (0.1 linear feet, 1989-2004) contains two folders that provide an overview of Affirmations. The first file, General Overview, features select documents that reflect the organization's overall philosophy and activities. The second file is of special note in that it contains the booklet entitled "The First Fifteen Years: An Anniversary Book" that chronicles the history and lifespan of Affirmations from 1989 to 2004. Additional information about the organization in general can also be found in the beginning of the Membership and Volunteers series.

did.unittitle: "The First Fifteen Years: An Anniversary Book," 1989-2004

scopecontent.p: The Governance series (1.0 linear feet, 1989-2002) encompasses the policies, regulations, and Board activities that guide the operation of Affirmations. The bulk of this series, the Meeting Records files, provides detailed minutes of the Board of Directors and committee meetings, including updates on financial, programmatic and planning processes. Note that, in addition to files for individual committees (Building, Fundraising, Membership, Policy, Program, Public Relations, Switchboard and Youth Services), select information might also be found within committee reports to the Board of Directors as a whole. Researchers may wish to use these meeting records to supplement more specific investigation of other series. All Meeting Records are organized chronologically.

The daily activities and management of Affirmations can be found in the Administration series (0.75 linear feet, 1990-2002). This includes several large Correspondence files whose content ranges from thank you notes sent by members to letters pertaining to the programs and activities of the organization. Researchers can gain a less formal view on Affirmations through these letters, which often provide a personal perspective on the circumstances surrounding the organization and its issues. Program and general planning, success metrics and staff notes can be found in the Reporting files.

The Grants section of the Grants and Fundraising series (0.75 linear feet, 1989-2001) is organized alphabetically by sponsor organization and includes submitted proposals and tracking for programs approved for funding. Many of these programs represent partnerships with other organizations to complement and supplement the groups and activities hosted solely by Affirmations. The Fundraising section of the Grants and Fundraising series represents select events designed to raise money for the organization. An additional revenue stream can be found in the Membership series through member dues and pledges. Administrative records of monetary planning can be found in the meeting records for the Board of Directors and/or the Fundraising Committee records.

did.unittitle: Oakland County Health Division/Office of Substance Abuse (Building Bridges)

scopecontent.p: The core functions of Affirmations can be found in the Programming series (1.0 linear feet, 1990-2002). The Events files present flyers publicizing the activities and events sponsored by Affirmations. This is followed by more extensive sections chronicling the planning, development and evaluation of specific events and activities. Programs have been categorized according to the nature of their function, as Recreation and Social Activities or as Community and Open Discussion Groups. Two additional areas of programming, the flagship Switchboard/Helpline and the increasingly important Youth Services, have been individually featured to include all procedural developments pertaining to these areas, from training to tracking to publicity. Further information about Youth Services might also be found in the Facilitators section of the Membership and Volunteers series. Researchers may also wish to consult the meeting records for the Board of Directors, Program Committee, Switchboard Committee and/or the Youth Services Committee for more administrative information.

scopecontent.p: The recruitment, training and general information for members can be found in the Membership and Volunteers series (0.75 linear feet, 1990-2000). The information and recruitment files are especially useful for general overviews of Affirmations, its philosophy, programs and overall presentation to the public. Several programs requiring trained volunteers have been isolated, most notably the Facilitators, who made the groups and other signature programs possible. Appreciation events, such as retreats and awards banquets, have also been included in this series.

The external face of Affirmations can be found in part in the Advocacy (0.25 linear feet, 1990-2001) series. This focuses on specific events or issues campaigned for or supported by Affirmations and is arranged alphabetically by the name of the event or cause.

The external face of Affirmations can also be found in the Publicity (0.2 linear feet, 1989-2003) series. This is organized chronologically and includes newspaper clippings and other stories about or pertaining to the organization. Also included are letters to editors and journalists in which Affirmations commends or condemns their coverage of gay and lesbian issues.

The final series, Photographs (0.2 linear feet, estimated 1997-2000), contains a selection of images depicting select events and activities. The year and date for some events have been provided, but the timeframe for many is unknown. They are projected to have occurred between 1997 and 2000.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Additional information about Affirmations can be found in a collection of newsletters produced by the organization and sent to Affirmations members and the general community. These have been catalogued in two record groups: Affirmations Lesbian/Gay Community Center 1989-1999 and Centerlines 1999-2004.
